document.text: gathering of the descendants of the late William Rosser. Mr. Rosser, a native of Fincastle, who had moved to Appomattox, was engaged in mak ing firearms in Richmond for the Confederacy during the War Be tween the States. At the close of hostilities he returned to Appomat tox. During the following years he had many and varied interests, in cluding a mercantile business, oper ating several farms, and serving as United States Postmaster for Appo mattox Court House. A buffet dinner was served in the house and on the lawn. The home was decorated with varigated sum mer flowers. All members of the family and guests registered on a large scroll provided for the occa sion. They wore white caps, with red decorations, on the front of which was inscribed, Rosser Clan. The surviving daughters of Mr. Rosser, Mrs. Clement A. Hancock of Huntington, West Va., and Mrs. Bessie Ferguson, of Roanoke and Appomattox, were crowned Queens for the day. document.text: Appomattox Democrats. The largest political meeting held in Appomattox couuty iu some years was that at this place on Tnursday, when toe Democratic voters of he county to the number of more than 300 met for the purpose of electiiiR delegates to the Eighteenth Distrust Senatorial Convention, and to no.in nate a  floater candidate for the House from Appomattox and Camp- hell. The senatorial convention lie- legation was instructed tor Hon. 11. 1. Flood, and Mr. J . R. Horsley re ceived the floater nomination. Both were inst ructed for Senator Atari in. The meeting was called to order by the county chairman, Mr, S. L. Ferguson, and Dr. J . B. Abbitt was made permanent chairman. Dr. D. Molt Robertson offered the follow - ing resoluliou, which was ui ani- mously adopted  In consideration of the eminent service the Hon. M. D. Flood has rendered this couuty, senatorial dis trict, and State as the representative of the Eigh eeur.h Senatorial District on the floor of the Senate, the abili ty he has displayed wherever ability lias been required, and the face that four years ago, against his own in clinations, he accepiled the almost unanimous call of his party lo i e its nominee for the Senate, we deem it but a simple act of justice, as it is to ns a great pleasure, to endorse his course and reconttnend him as his own successor. Mr. Flood nominated Mr. J . R. Horsley aud Dr. T. B. Rucker nom inated Allen il. Clement for floater delegate to the Houser Hr. Robertson moved that a viva- voce xote be taken, which was unex pected by the Clement people, who hud expected that a dividing line would be ilravui when the vote was taken. Still, not a disuniting voice was heard, aud Air. Horsley was de clared tne nominee. Quite a num ber of the auditors held themselves aloot, and would not participate in the meeting. Although there were many known Tyler men in the audience, none of them had a word to say. Like the Clement followers, ihey appeared, to be merely spectators. Mr. S. P. Coleman offered the fol lowing, which was adopted witnout a dissenting voice  Whereas, the Hon. Thomas S. Martin is the choice of the Demo crats of Appomattox county as his own successor as United States Sen atorfirst, because, owing to his high character, great intellect, and executive ability, he is a worthy col league of Virginias senior Senator, Hon. John W. Daniel second, be cause by his votes, influence, and voice he has aided the great cause of the free and unlimited coinage of silver the struggle which is ev erywhere being made against trusts aud combines, having voted to tax their products has fought the un limited issue of bonds has advocat ed the principles of the income-tax, aud by every act and vote has shown himself to be in perfect accord with the principles of the Virginia De mocracy  third, because of his loyal aud effective services iu his fight against the increase of the tuternal- revenue tax on tobacco fourth, be cause during his entire life he has given much of his time aud means to nnautaiu the supremacy of the Democratic party in Virginia aud in the nation, and has in all of our struggles been particularly helpful to the Democrats of the Black Belt therefore, be it  Resolved, That the delegates to bp appointed to the senatorial and legislative conventions be, and they are hereby, instructed to vote to in struct the nominees of their respect ive con veil  iu 8 to vote for the re- election of the Hon. Thos. S. Mar tin to the United States Senate. The Democratic Executive Com mittee was reorganized as follows Saml L. Ferguson, chairman J . C. Jones, A. H. Howerton, S. J . Lee, J . W. Clark, W. J . Trent, W. H. Ligon, A. B. Thornhill, W. C. Abbitt, S. C. Stratton. R. H. OBrien aud M. F. Kyle were succeeded on the committee by Wm. J . Trent and A. B. Thornhill. There was no opposition to any of the members. After the meeting adjourned, Capt. W. D. Johns spoke for some time iu favor of Governor Tyler for I United States Senator. Supervisor Ligon called for the vote on the fence question and the crowd was asked to separate. The i result was the  no fencers carried the day and the boundary line of  each farm or tract of laud shall hereafter be held to be a lawful fence.

document.text: IN THE APPOMATTOX  BUCKINGHAM TIMES August 1, 1906 Parker, Horsley of Bent Creek, died July 21. Buria services were conducted by V S. Reed of the Y. M. C. A. There will be a big circus-in town Saturday. Dr. W. H- Abbitt improves His son, Rev. William Abbitt of Kentucky, is visiting him. Master Braxton Hancock en tertained a number of his lit friends in the celebration of his birthday last Tuesday. Mrs. Sallie Blackwell, wife of Allen O. Blackwell, died at her home yesterday afternoon The deceased was formerly Miss Godsey, of Appomattox County. Sam Thornton of Graham was the guest of his sister, Mrs B- T. Gunter, of Evergreen, last week. Miss Bessie Thornhill of Lynchburg is a guest of Miss Fannie Clement. Lightning struck an old oak tree about forty years old in the yard of Mrs. Hubbard Mar tin and tore it to pieces last Friday evening.  Bob Davis, Squire Womack, and Wells Chittenden of Pamp- lin were in the village Monday on business. I Robert Oder has been visit ing in the county for several days. He haspurchased a nice farm here and will, we hope, again make his home among us. A concert will be given in Smiths Hall next Friday night for the benefit of the Metho dist sidwalk fund. Misses Ethel Calhoun a n d Lucy Gills are visiting in Lynch burg. mss Brown, of Crewe is a guest ot Miss Rosa Paris. --------------- 0 ---------------
